Some single payer v police funding differences
For the most part police, not federal law enforcement is funded at the local level and their costs for the most part are clearly spelled out in budgets and proposals. Police Departments are free to pay their officers as they please and local governments tax for them as needed. Some towns give one a bill straight up for emergency services, it's cost is not hidden in one big tax number. Also local policing frequently share duties along with backing each other up at the county or neighboring town level. Single payer would need a federal tax increase along among other things including reallocating and locating resources.
With policing, the officer gets paid hourly for the most part, maybe some overtime or comp time along the way. The police get paid the same wether they rescue a cat or have a shoot out or chase a suspect. Doctors, health care providers want or are paid by the procedure which would be like the police charging extra for a robbery vs a noise complaint.
Also to make single payer government enforced health care work not only would require new taxes but it would wind up allocating resources meaning one's now convenient hospital might move it's services 10 miles away. In our county the regional hospitals are already designated during off hours ie a burn patient goes here, a broken leg goes there etc. meaning one could pass a hospital on their way to the ER. Also more importantly doctors and/or health care workers become defacto government employees meaning many will become hourly or salaried employees rather than billing by the job. Also means more clinic style medicine which might not be as bad but people want the convenience of an appointment. Wait times will go up to see the doc and get a non emergent procedure done.
Also in many countries with single payer their population numbers, demographics, politics, culture, economics, other systems/services are different. It's not just a matter of unplugging US health care and plugging in single payer. It would NOT be plug in and play.

But just as important as testing is getting fresh air/ventilator hose down in the hole or confined space to displace the gases that have built up. If it's a street manhole it's subject to run off on the street so that could petroleum products, food/grease etc. Also Florida being at sea level the moisture soil content of a hole probably allows for different gases to build.

WRITING.TEXT:
St Louis or most cities don't build or refurbish stadiums without somekind of preliminary agreement. Few to zero projects municipal or private get started without at least a verbal agreement of some kind. Once full fledged contracts are signed with these teams they are loaded with clauses(Which St Louis did sign) that include calling for upgrades every time a new stadium is built elsewhere. Most cities can't keep up.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-sports-nfl-stadiums-insight-idUSKCN0VC0EP
Point is cities lose out building and maintaining millionaire playgrounds. No matter what's promised up front becomes more meaningless as the years go by.

The initial deal and numbers had the builders/owners getting over 100 million in the form of tax breaks and I think LA has to provide security for events.
Tax breaks can bounce back. St Louis has to pick up what the Rams promised years ago.

Federal tax payers will be paying over a billion dollars for LA's railine extension. The administration just awarded LA over a BILLION dollars. If LA had funded all or more on their own I doubt they would be that eager to award tax breaks for that new stadium.
There have been complaints in the past from cities that have been told by the NFL to waive their city hotel taxes during the Super Bowl build up for 2 weeks. This is one reason many cities "lose".

I still hear things like 16 agencies concluded... But the Russian "hack" story keeps changing.
First it was the Russians, then 16 agencies 'concluded'-or gave their "opinion", the it was the 13 page report with maybe one page of possible evidence, the another 33 page report short on evidence but again loaded 'conclusions' then Trump was briefed and someone asked about the Russian Hack and Trump gave a thought among many others.
To top it off "hack" is over used, maybe scammed or trapped since the likes of Podesta answered a virus loaded email/message not a "hack" per say.

Most regardless of profession don't like rude treatment and no matter how professional they claim to be a doctor can be affected. Most people take things personally and will "screw you" verbally and action wise. Those who tend not to let themselves get distracted and stay focused on the task/s at hand are the ones that will succeed or excel in life in general.
ANYONE who deals with the public, customers etc has to expect 'rude' treatment. It would be nice if everyone could just get along but that is not reality. Doctors and others should know expect it.
I've always found the bouncer training scene in the movie Roadhouse to be most effective in real life as well in which Patrick Swayze tells them "Be nice" no matter what the patron does.
